trans-unit.source: Getting the Gist of Markdown's Formatting Syntax

seg-source.mrk: Getting the Gist of Markdown's Formatting Syntax

target.mrk: Getting the Gist of Markdown's Formatting Syntax

trans-unit.source: This page offers a brief overview of what it's like to use Markdown. The [syntax page] [s] provides complete, detailed documentation for every feature, but Markdown should be very easy to pick up simply by looking at a few examples of it in action. The examples on this page are written in a before/after style, showing example syntax and the HTML output produced by Markdown.

seg-source.mrk: This page offers a brief overview of what it's like to use Markdown.
The [syntax page] [s] provides complete, detailed documentation for
every feature, but Markdown should be very easy to pick up simply by
looking at a few examples of it in action.
are written in a before/after style, showing example syntax and the

trans-unit.source: It's also helpful to simply try Markdown out; the [Dingus] [d] is a web application that allows you type your own Markdown-formatted text and translate it to XHTML.

web application that allows you type your own Markdown-formatted text

target.mrk: It's also helpful to simply try Markdown out; the [Dingus] [d] is a
web application that allows you type your own Markdown-formatted text

trans-unit.source: **Note:** This document is itself written using Markdown; you can [see the source for it by adding '.text' to the URL] [src].

can [see the source for it by adding '.text' to the URL] [src].

trans-unit.source: A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated by one or more blank lines. (A blank line is any line that looks like a blank line -- a line containing nothing spaces or tabs is considered blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be intended with spaces or tabs.

seg-source.mrk: A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated
by one or more blank lines.
(A blank line is any line that looks like a
blank line -- a line containing nothing spaces or tabs is considered
blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be intended with spaces or tabs.

target.mrk: A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated
by one or more blank lines.
(A blank line is any line that looks like a
blank line -- a line containing nothing spaces or tabs is considered
blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be intended with spaces or tabs.

trans-unit.source: Markdown offers two styles of headers: *Setext* and *atx*. Setext-style headers for `<h1>` and `<h2>` are created by "underlining" with equal signs (`=`) and hyphens (`-`), respectively. To create an atx-style header, you put 1-6 hash marks (`#`) at the beginning of the line -- the number of hashes equals the resulting HTML header level.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown offers two styles of headers: *Setext* and *atx*.

To create an atx-style header, you put 1-6 hash marks (`#`) at the
beginning of the line -- the number of hashes equals the resulting

trans-unit.source: Blockquotes are indicated using email-style '`>`' angle brackets.

seg-source.mrk: Blockquotes are indicated using email-style '`>`' angle brackets.

target.mrk: Blockquotes are indicated using email-style '`>`' angle brackets.

trans-unit.source:
A First Level Header ====================
A Second Level Header ---------------------
Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country. This is just a regular paragraph.
The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog's back.
### Header 3
> This is a blockquote. > > This is the second paragraph in the blockquote. > > ## This is an H2 in a blockquote

### Header 3

trans-unit.source: Markdown uses asterisks and underscores to indicate spans of emphasis.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown uses asterisks and underscores to indicate spans of emphasis.

target.mrk: Markdown uses asterisks and underscores to indicate spans of emphasis.

trans-unit.source:
Some of these words *are emphasized*. Some of these words _are emphasized also_.
Use two asterisks for **strong emphasis**. Or, if you prefer, __use two underscores instead__.

seg-source.mrk:
Some of these words *are emphasized*. Some of these words _are emphasized also_.
Use two asterisks for **strong emphasis**. Or, if you prefer, __use two underscores instead__.

target.mrk:
Some of these words *are emphasized*. Some of these words _are emphasized also_.
Use two asterisks for **strong emphasis**. Or, if you prefer, __use two underscores instead__.

Some of these words are emphasized. Some of these words are emphasized also.

Use two asterisks for strong emphasis. Or, if you prefer, use two underscores instead.

target.mrk:
Some of these words are emphasized. Some of these words are emphasized also.

Use two asterisks for strong emphasis. Or, if you prefer, use two underscores instead.

trans-unit.source: Unordered (bulleted) lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens (`*`, `+`, and `-`) as list markers. These three markers are interchangable; this:

seg-source.mrk: Unordered (bulleted) lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens (`*`,

target.mrk: Unordered (bulleted) lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens (`*`,

trans-unit.source: Ordered (numbered) lists use regular numbers, followed by periods, as list markers:

seg-source.mrk: Ordered (numbered) lists use regular numbers, followed by periods, as

target.mrk: Ordered (numbered) lists use regular numbers, followed by periods, as

trans-unit.source: Markdown supports two styles for creating links: *inline* and *reference*. With both styles, you use square brackets to delimit the text you want to turn into a link.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown supports two styles for creating links: *inline* and
With both styles, you use square brackets to delimit the
text you want to turn into a link.

target.mrk: Markdown supports two styles for creating links: *inline* and
With both styles, you use square brackets to delimit the
text you want to turn into a link.

trans-unit.source: Inline-style links use parentheses immediately after the link text. For example:

seg-source.mrk: Inline-style links use parentheses immediately after the link text.

target.mrk: Inline-style links use parentheses immediately after the link text.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you may include a title attribute in the parentheses:

seg-source.mrk: Optionally, you may include a title attribute in the parentheses:

target.mrk: Optionally, you may include a title attribute in the parentheses:

trans-unit.source: This is an [example link](http://example.com/ "With a Title").

seg-source.mrk: This is an [example link](http://example.com/ "With a Title").

target.mrk: This is an [example link](http://example.com/ "With a Title").

trans-unit.source: This is an example link.

seg-source.mrk: This is an example link.

target.mrk: This is an example link.

trans-unit.source: Reference-style links allow you to refer to your links by names, which you define elsewhere in your document:

seg-source.mrk: Reference-style links allow you to refer to your links by names, which
you define elsewhere in your document:

target.mrk: Reference-style links allow you to refer to your links by names, which
you define elsewhere in your document:

trans-unit.source:
I get 10 times more traffic from [Google][1] than from [Yahoo][2] or [MSN][3].
[1]: http://google.com/ "Google" [2]: http://search.yahoo.com/ "Yahoo Search" [3]: http://search.msn.com/ "MSN Search"

seg-source.mrk:
I get 10 times more traffic from [Google][1] than from [Yahoo][2] or [MSN][3].
[1]: http://google.com/ "Google" [2]: http://search.yahoo.com/ "Yahoo Search" [3]: http://search.msn.com/ "MSN Search"

target.mrk:
I get 10 times more traffic from [Google][1] than from [Yahoo][2] or [MSN][3].
[1]: http://google.com/ "Google" [2]: http://search.yahoo.com/ "Yahoo Search" [3]: http://search.msn.com/ "MSN Search"

trans-unit.source: I get 10 times more traffic from Google than from Yahoo or MSN.

seg-source.mrk: I get 10 times more traffic from Google than from Yahoo or MSN.

target.mrk: I get 10 times more traffic from Google than from Yahoo or MSN.

trans-unit.source: The title attribute is optional. Link names may contain letters, numbers and spaces, but are *not* case sensitive:

seg-source.mrk: numbers and spaces, but are *not* case sensitive:

target.mrk: numbers and spaces, but are *not* case sensitive:

trans-unit.source:
I start my morning with a cup of coffee and [The New York Times][NY Times].
[ny times]: http://www.nytimes.com/

seg-source.mrk:
I start my morning with a cup of coffee and [The New York Times][NY Times].
[ny times]: http://www.nytimes.com/

target.mrk:
I start my morning with a cup of coffee and [The New York Times][NY Times].
[ny times]: http://www.nytimes.com/

trans-unit.source: I start my morning with a cup of coffee and The New York Times.

seg-source.mrk: I start my morning with a cup of coffee and The New York Times.

target.mrk: I start my morning with a cup of coffee and The New York Times.

trans-unit.source: Image syntax is very much like link syntax.

seg-source.mrk: Image syntax is very much like link syntax.

target.mrk: Image syntax is very much like link syntax.

trans-unit.source: In a regular paragraph, you can create code span by wrapping text in backtick quotes. Any ampersands (`&`) and angle brackets (`<` or `>`) will automatically be translated into HTML entities. This makes it easy to use Markdown to write about HTML example code:

Any ampersands (`&`) and angle brackets (`<` or
`>`) will automatically be translated into HTML entities.
it easy to use Markdown to write about HTML example code:

Any ampersands (`&`) and angle brackets (`<` or
`>`) will automatically be translated into HTML entities.
it easy to use Markdown to write about HTML example code:

trans-unit.source:
I strongly recommend against using any `<blink>` tags.
I wish SmartyPants used named entities like `—` instead of decimal-encoded entites like `—`.

I wish SmartyPants used named entities like `—` instead of decimal-encoded entites like `—`.

trans-unit.source: To specify an entire block of pre-formatted code, indent every line of the block by 4 spaces or 1 tab. Just like with code spans, `&`, `<`, and `>` characters will be escaped automatically.

seg-source.mrk: To specify an entire block of pre-formatted code, indent every line of
the block by 4 spaces or 1 tab.
and `>` characters will be escaped automatically.

target.mrk: To specify an entire block of pre-formatted code, indent every line of
the block by 4 spaces or 1 tab.
and `>` characters will be escaped automatically.

trans-unit.source:
If you want your page to validate under XHTML 1.0 Strict, you've got to put paragraph tags in your blockquotes:

For example.

seg-source.mrk:
If you want your page to validate under XHTML 1.0 Strict, you've got to put paragraph tags in your blockquotes:

For example.

target.mrk:
If you want your page to validate under XHTML 1.0 Strict, you've got to put paragraph tags in your blockquotes:

For example.

trans-unit.source:
If you want your page to validate under XHTML 1.0 Strict, you've got to put paragraph tags in your blockquotes:

<blockquote>
    <p>For example.</p>
    </blockquote>

seg-source.mrk:
If you want your page to validate under XHTML 1.0 Strict, you've got to put paragraph tags in your blockquotes:

<blockquote>
    <p>For example.</p>
    </blockquote>

    </blockquote>
